Award.AwardTitle: EFRI-2DARE and NewLAW Grantees Meeting Workshop, San Diego, October 17-19, 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project seeks financial support to support a workshop to be held October 17-19, 2018 at the Sheraton San Diego Hotel and Marina CA. The Workshop will bring together the NSF EFRI Two- Dimensional Atomic-Layer Research and Engineering (2-DARE), as well as New Light, EM (Electronic) and Acoustic Wave Propagation: Breaking Reciprocity and Time Reversal Symmetry (NewLAW) supported researchers working on materials and devices in these areas to help promote future collaborations and address common challenges. This includes faculty, postdoctoral researcher and graduate students from the institutions supported by the 2-DARE and NewLAW programs. The Workshop is expected to play a key role in addressing in detail currently faced bottlenecks in material and device research and identifying new directions for research. The research discussed at the Workshop is expected to lead to technological breakthroughs and disruptive technologies that can have great societal impact in the future in many areas such as sensing, communications and health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was to organize the NSF EFRI-2DARE&NewLAW Grantees Meeting, on Oct.17-19, 2018 in Sheraton San Diego Hotel and Marina CA. The workshop follows (with one day overlap) the “BiCMOS and Compound Semiconductor Integrated Circuits and Technology Symposium”, which takes place October 14-17,2018 in San Diego to gain synergy and opportunity for emphasizing the device and application driven expectations form these two EFRI programs.

The purpose of the proposal is to support organization of the EFRI-2DARE&NewLAW Grantees’ Annual Meeting for the entire awardees in the past 2 years. About 35 performing teams (20 teams for 2DARE and 15 teams for NewLAW) and more than 150 attendees joined the worlkshop. This event assembled the national scientific community to a common stage to steer discussion towards scientific and engineering research progress in both the area of layered materials and reciprocity breaking.

The intellectual merit and broader impacts of this meeting can be summarized below:

 Discussion on 2D material research and reciprocity breaking applications in electromagnetic waves and optical light in terms of currently existing efforts and where they will lead to. In particular, the attendees had discussion of common challenges and solutions and fostered collaboration among researchers of EFRI would benefit research advancement. The interdisciplinary nature of the workshop has provided unique experienes to many attendents who are graduate students and postdocs.
